awd_titl_txt: Type I: Invent Penn State I-Corps Site
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, from Penn State University, creates an I-Corps Site at this institution.

NSF Innovation Corps (I-Corps) Sites are NSF-funded entities established at universities whose purpose is to nurture and support multiple, local teams to transition their technology concepts into the marketplace. Sites provide infrastructure, advice, resources, networking opportunities, training and modest funding to enable groups to transition their work into the marketplace or into becoming I-Corps Team applicants. I-Corps Sites also strengthen innovation locally and regionally and contribute to the National Innovation Network of mentors, researchers, entrepreneurs and investors.

The Penn State I-Corps Site, operated under the umbrella of the Invent Penn State Initiative and the Office of Entrepreneurship and Commercialization, supports the translation of university research, develops partnerships between the university and regional economic development organizations and the national I-Corps Network, and trains students to be the drivers of research commercialization.

The Penn State I-Corps Site teams that pursue commercialization through two different programs, the TechCelerator@State College and the Happy Valley LaunchBox. These two programs are structured to nurture innovator teams using Lean Startup methodology and embody the notion of nurturing innovators both with deep craft and fresh eyes, that is, people with some who have depth of technical expertise as well as those with a fresh perspective on new markets, communication technologies, and consumer concepts. The TechCelerator Program, established in 2011 seeks to accelerate the commercialization of University technology. The Happy Valley Launchbox, created in 2015, is a community-university accelerator that makes extensive use of Lean Startup principles and Design Thinking to help teams bring their ideas into the marketplace. The I-Corps Site program provides funds to teams that are either selected out of one of these programs or have members combined from both programs to support the translation of university technology. The I-Corps Site also engages the broad network of Penn State Innovation hubs across the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania.

The outcomes of this project have the potential for significant broader impacts across the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania and the region. Initial activity focuses on Penn State's main University Park Campus. However, Invent Penn State operates 13 community innovation hubs throughout the State, affiliated with the University's network of Commonwealth campuses. In addition, the Penn State I-Corps Site, in collaboration with the Upstate New York regional I-Corps Node will run summer programs to train leaders from the commonwealth innovation hubs in Lean startup methodology and will engage their promising teams with the Upstate New York (UNY) regional I-Corps Node.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The Invent Penn State NSF I-Corps Site Award helped to significantly advance innovation and entrepreneurship education across the Pennsylvania Commonwealth. Through microgrants designed to support customer discovery efforts, over 135 teams consisting of undergraduates, graduate students, postdocs, faculty, researchers, and community members worked through I-Corps-affiliated training programs to explore the commercial potential of their business ideas. Many teams used this funding to attend conferences or trade shows, or to travel to established businesses in their domain to learn about pain points the market was experiencing. Through utilizing tools including the Business Model Canvas, teams were challenged to explore if product-market fit, or problem-solution fit alignment existed between their solution and the pain points they discovered.

Throughout the duration of the Site award, Penn State focused on achieving 4 main goals:

  1. To enhance existing startup education programs and customer discovery at Penn State by sharing best practices and connecting educators with the I-Corps national network: Penn State embraced learning from the National Innovation Network for the duration of the Site grant. Penn State engaged with instructors from the Upper New York I-Corps Node in 2019 to learn best practices for running effective I-Corps short courses designed primarily for faculty members, graduate students, and postdocs. These best practices were also shared with Penn State’s 21 Launchboxes and innovation spaces to help them refine I-Corps-affiliated training programs including Idea TestLab and FastTrack Accelerator.
  2. To deepen connections with regional businesses and commercialization experts in the education of our research faculty and student populations: This goal evolved throughout the years, with an early focus on increasing the awareness of NSF I-Corps as a program around the Commonwealth; this led to the majority of the teams receiving microgrants consisting of undergraduate students and working through an I-Corps-affiliated training program. Starting in 2021, the focus began to shift towards graduate student and faculty-led teams with Penn State intellectual property (or the potential to develop it) who were working through an NSF I-Corps Short Course offered by Penn State.
  3. To become a dynamic resource for Lean startup education for personnel at Penn State’s 21 Innovation Hubs across Pennsylvania: Drawing on NSF I-Corps’ focus on experiential learning and Lean Launchpad (LLP) methodology, many members of Penn State’s LaunchBox and Innovation Network, consisting of 21 LaunchBoxes and innovation spaces, began offering customer discovery-focused programs like Idea TestLab and FastTrack Accelerator. These programs challenged teams to get “out of the building” and talk to potential customers as well as industry experts to determine if product market fit existed between their business idea and the pain points of the market. Penn State also worked with Ben Franklin Technology Partners, a statewide technology-based economic development program, to help refine the TechCelerator, a 10-week business bootcamp designed to help teams launch their startup.
  4. To offer Lean LaunchPad education and commercialization training to graduate student and faculty-led teams through running short courses that prepare teams to apply for the NSF I-Corps Teams program: Coming out of the COVID-19 pandemic, Penn State began to focus more heavily on offering NSF I-Corps short courses to graduate students, postdocs, faculty members, and researchers who were working on commercializing federally funded research in a deep tech field. These courses were offered virtually, allowing teams from across the Commonwealth to easily participate, and were designed to help teams determine whether advancing to the I-Corps National Teams Program was an appropriate next step. In total, 11 of these courses were run over the duration of the Site grant.

In addition to advancing these 4 goals, Penn State also remained cognoscente of the intellectual merit impacts of the Site grant. To this end, the project advanced the understanding and application of entrepreneurship education within an academic setting. We found the Lean LaunchPad (LLP) methodology of experiential learning worked well across academic disciplines. 

In conclusion, throughout the tenure of the I-Corps Site award, Penn State leveraged the program to enhance startup education, strengthen regional partnerships though our LaunchBox and innovation space network, and promote research commercialization. As we transition into our new role as a Partner in the NSF I-Corps Mid Atlantic Hub, Penn State remains committed to fostering entrepreneurship and innovation for the benefit of our university and society at large.


Last Modified: 01/15/2025
Modified by: Derek M Gross
